Posts.Content: I'm anaemic because of very heavy periods so the oncologist has me on 200mg of iron 3 times a day in tablet form. Posts.Content: Hi Jackie Rant all you like! That's one of the great things about this forum, it's such a relief to be able to rant about anything and everything. I found working again a big milestone as it marked a return to some sort of normality...albeit a different normal from before. What I do find hard is people's sympathy and kindness, it makes me cry! So I don't like it when I'm treated with kid gloves and yet sometimes I want to shout "Ahem! Cancer patient here! Let's have some sympathy!" A few weeks ago my son got married and it was the first time I'd seen any family for over a year. Oh my word! I was so fed up with "Don't you look well. I'd thought you'd look really sick." We can't win. Emotions all over the place and unpredictable. People won't let us just come back into the world as if we'd nipped out for a loaf of bread when that's how we want it (and they won't fawn over us when we want that sometimes). I have one friend who asks in hushed tones if I'm alright...one day I may just yell "No, I've had blooming breast cancer. Of course I'm not alright" because I think that's what he wants to hear. His intentions are good though. I've rambled, sorry. I guess I'm trying to say it does get easier. Cancer scares people and they don't know how to treat us so we have to let them know by example how we want to be treated. Rebecca x

Posts.Content: The Sunday Times contacted me. Of course, they published such a teeny tiny quote that they made me sound ungrateful. http://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/cancer-survivors-dismiss-bravery-of-charitys-head-shave-fundraising-vfmh7btr8 Here what I actually said: It’s hard to write this without sounding like a bitter ungrateful old bag! I am not that at all and am often hesitant to comment negatively lest I appear so. Fund raising is a wonderful thing and lord knows, without it I wouldn’t be here today but sometimes people get it wrong. Macmillan raise vast amounts and for this I am truly grateful but the wording this time was wrong. There is nothing brave about shaving your head! I understand it’s something people frequently do in support of friends or family and that Macmillan felt it would be an opportunity missed but that word BRAVE…no, it’s not. Shave your head, shave your eyebrows, pull out your eyelashes, endure surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, hormone therapy and all the never ending, permanent side effects of treatment and even that’s not brave. We have no choice. It’s that or die…not much of a choice.   This is what I wrote in the Macmillan forum:   I hate the campaign. There is nothing brave about shaving your head and I love the term "hero martyr". When I see people doing this I want to say "Oh cool, well done. Now you need to have six months of chemo and surgery...not so brave now, huh?!" I'd rather people just gave the money. When these brave souls look in the mirror do they see a shaved head, money raised and even feel a little smug? When I looked in the mirror I saw a life threatening illness. I was not aware of the Marks and Spencer Bra Strap campaign so I looked it up. Hmmm…I should think it was very upsetting to those women who no longer have anything to put in a bra. Even reconstructions (as I have) don’t sit well in a bra. On top of all this, the nature of social media can make it all so much worse. The “look at me” culture, the filtered selfies really rub it in. It’s easy to take a selfie of your pretty bra strap, with your hair looking lovely and your skin soft and dewy. It reminds us of what we’ve lost. Also, the amount of people joining in with trending hashtags, contributing nothing is galling. I do not wish to sound bitter nor ungrateful but if I sound resentful, I am. I cannot stress enough how grateful I am to people who raise money for research and care. Twenty years ago my cancer may well have killed me. Because of these generous people I saw my son get married, I had coffee in the garden at 6.00 am today, I will have another forty years of garden mornings with my wonderful husband (I fully intend to reach 100!) But please, don’t rub it in. Don’t remind me, don’t make me feel a lesser woman. During my treatment I wrote this on my blog: Not angry… I’ve realised it’s not anger I feel, nor injustice, nor even WTF? but resentment. A couple of months ago I was unaware that I had breast cancer. I was fit and healthy, stupidly happy, had reached a very good turning point in my work and was loving it. Finances had been tight but TB and I were just getting it all sorted. Life was blooming good! I think a lot of us keep quiet about feeling like this because we should just be grateful for our treatment (and I am) but I hate that my life has been changed FOREVER. I loved it just the way it was, thank you very much xx I am a big believer in Pay it Forward and two or three times a year I donate a portrait for a charity to auction. This makes me feel good, very good but never brave.   Regards Rebecca

(I've also had my ovaries removed to help reduce any further risk). I've had hormone treatment and now have drugs for four more years and some forever. The treatment was tough but it was do-able and I'm here and have every intention of being here for many many many years to come. I have complete faith in the treatment I've had and the drugs I now take. I've kicked cancer's butt! Rebecca x PS: I even have hair again  :o)

Posts.Title: Getting to the end of treatment - then what?

Posts.Content: It just goes on and on. Breast cancer treatment has caused me to lose my hair, be at risk of lymphodema, lose my breasts, damaged my nails, endure all sorts of chemo side effects, permanent discomfort from radiotherapy, had ovaries removed (I was ER+) so now had menopause. Menopause has led to vaginal atrophy and now the beginnings of prolapse, which cannot be sorted the most effective way because I cannot have anything containing estrogen. As yet, all these permanent knock on effects are manageable but I  have no doubt they will get worse and more will arise. I've had cancer...was that not enough bollox for me? Do I have to have all this other sh*t, too? I am soooooo pi**ed off today...can you tell? Normal service will be resumed, I'm sure.  I'm damaged, not broken. (Still pi**ed off, though!) Rebecca x
Posts.Title: Is cancer not enough?!

Posts.Content: Oh ladies, thank you all so much. I had a routine appointment with my oncologist today and he doesn't want to see me for a year. It's very strange. I want to see him every month so he can tell me I'm ok! I shall get a referral to the gynaecologist as soon as I can get an appointment with my GP. I'm hoping I'll see the same chap who whipped out my ovaries...I like him., his needle work is awesome! I've been prodded and poked and had many orifices peered into from all angles so much over the last couple of years...it's a good job I'm not shy  ;o) All the niggles are reminders so do we ever totally lose the fear? My husband says I didn't think every twinge or ache was cancer before all this but then that was before I'd ever had cancer.  So that's another thing it's done for me...taken away some carefree-ness. (is that even a word? It is now!) Having had my angry moment, I consider myself lucky. Cancer is treatable and in most cases never returns. I have friends with chronic, degenerative illnesses (MS, AS, MND) and they will never improve. I thank my lucky stars I only had cancer. "I only had cancer"...not a sentence I ever thought I'd say. I guess, what I'm angry at is that I loved my life just the way it was. Now it's different. It's still blooming good, but I didn't want it to change and feel I lost control for a while. I shall retake command and run this show just the way I want to. F*ck you, cancer...consider your ass well and truly kicked! Yay!!!!! Rebecca x PS Still a titchy bit scared though...

Posts.Content: This was my blog post a couple of months after my diagnosis: August 16, 2012 Not angry… I’ve realised it’s not anger I feel, nor injustice, nor even WTF? but resentment. A couple of months ago I was unaware that I had breast cancer. I was fit and healthy, stupidly happy, had reached a very good turning point in my work and was loving it. Finances had been tight but TB and I were just getting it all sorted. Life was blooming good! I think a lot of us keep quiet about feeling like this because we should just be grateful for our treatment (and I am) but I hate that my life has been changed FOREVER. I loved it just the way it was, thank you very much xx   Two years later I still feel that resentment.
